fields.label: Pizza Size
fields.jbTooltipContent: How big would you like your pizza?

fields.label: Number of pizzas
fields.jbTooltipContent: The amount of pizzas you would like.

fields.label: Do you want to make your pizza dough?

choices.text: No, I already have dough ready
Yes, I would like to make the dough

fields.label: When do you want it?
fields.jbTooltipContent: This determines the preperation time for your pizza. The longer the preparation time, the better the flavour and texture of the pizza. For best results, choose '2 days' here.

fields.label: Yeast type
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the yeast type that you will be using. The most common type of yeast is 'Active Dry Yeast'. The label on your yeast packet/container should state whether it is Active or Instant. Fresh yeast is not as common (as dry yeasts) in western countries, and is more likely to be found only in specialty stores.

fields.label: Starter
fields.jbTooltipContent: A starter is a natural leavening agent used in pizza dough to enhance flavor and texture. Choose a starter that matches your pizza style from the options provided. If you're unsure, leave the default selection 'None'. For custom pizza types, use our advanced calculator (advanced calculator).

fields.label: Starter
fields.jbTooltipContent: A starter is a natural leavening agent used in pizza dough to enhance flavor and texture. Choose a starter that matches your pizza style from the options provided. If you're unsure, leave the default selection 'None'. For custom pizza types, use our advanced calculator (advanced calculator).

fields.label: Starter Statement
fields.content:
This type of dough requires a Sourdough starter. Click on our Sourdough starter recipe link to learn how to create one!
Learn the recipe!

fields.label: HTML Block
fields.content:
Dough adjustments
We've chosen the best dough settings based on your pizza selection, however if you're an advanced pizza creator, feel free to change them.

fields.label: Hydration (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent:
This is the % of water that will be used compared to the total flour. For example, if the hydration is set to 60% and the total flour is 100gm, then the water will be 60gm. 

The most common hydration has been selected for your pizza type.

fields.label: Sourdough Starter (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of Sourdough starter you will make your total pizza dough with. For example, if you are making a 100g ms dough ball, and you use 20% of Sourdough starter, then your sourdough starter will be 20 gms.

fields.label: Biga flour (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of the total flour you want to use for your starter. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered!

fields.label: Poolish flour (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of the total flour you want to use for your starter. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered!

fields.label: Salt (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of salt you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Sugar (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of sugar you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Oil (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of oil you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Dough Balls
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is basically the number of pizzas you have chosen. Each dough ball will form 1 x pizza.

fields.label: Dough Ball Weight
fields.calculationFormula:
if({Pizza Size:220} == 10):
((((10/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 11 ):
((((11/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 12 ):
((((12/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 14 ):
((((14/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 16 ):
((((16/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 18 ):
((((18/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 20 ):
((((20/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 100001):
((({Pizza Length (cm):242}*{Pizza Width (cm):243})*{Dough Weight Per Square CM:255}))
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 100002):
((({Pizza Length (inches):248}*{Pizza Width (inches):247})*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254}))
else:
  0
endif;
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the recommended dough ball weight for your chosen pizza. If we prefer to customise your own dough ball weight, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: RT Leavening time (hours)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the recommended Room Temperature (RT) leavening/fermenting time for your starter or dough (in the beginning). If you prefer to customise your own temperature, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: Yeast %
HTML Block
fields.content: How do you want to display the results?

fields.label: Show dough calculator results?
fields.description: You can view the breakdown of ingredients from our dough calculator based on your selections above. Otherwise go straight to the recipe (don't worry, the ingredients will be displayed on the next step as well).

fields.label: Hidden - Sourdough Flour gm
fields.calculationFormula: ({Dough ball weight (gms):4}*{Number of pizzas:246})/((({Hidden - Sourdough Total Percentages:245}/100)+({Sourdough Starter (%):114}/100))+1)

fields.label: Hidden - Sourdough Salt gm
fields.calculationFormula: (({Hidden - Sourdough Starter gm:124}/2)+{Hidden - Sourdough Flour gm:115})*({Salt (%):17}/100)

fields.label: Hidden - Sourdough RT Ferement Time
fields.calculationFormula:
if({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 15):
18
elseif({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 20):
12
elseif({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 25):
8
elseif({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 30):
4
else:
  0
endif;

confirmations.name: Default Confirmation
confirmations.message:
1. Preparing the Poolish Starter

1) Add the {Hidden - Poolish Water (gm/ml):27}gms of water to a bowl. Make sure it's luke warm 2) Now add the {Hidden - Poolish Yeast (gms):28}gms of yeast and the {Hidden - Poolish Sugar (gms):56}gms of sugar into the bowl and stir well. Let this sit for about 10 minutes before the next ste. 3) Now add the  {Hidden - Poolish Flour (gm):26}gms of flour and mix until all is combined. 4) Now let this sit for {Leavening time (hours):12} hours at {RT Temperature (celsius):7} celsius. 5) After {Leavening time (hours):12} hours, you're now ready to move to step 2 'Making the dough'

2. Making the dough

1) Once your poolish is ready, it's time to start adding the remaining ingredients to form your pizza dough. 2) Take a mixing bown, and add {Hidden - Dough Flour (gms):29} gms of flour to the bowl 3) Now add {Hidden - Dough Water (gm/mil):30} gms/mls of water to the bowl 4) Now add {Dough Salt (gms):70} gms of salt to add some flavour 5) Also add {Dough Oil (gms):71} gms of oil to the bowl 6) And now add your starter or poolish to the bowl and mix all together 7) Once all mixed together...............

confirmations.name: Poolish Recipe Description
confirmations.message:
[gravityforms action="conditional" merge_tag="{When do you want it?:229:value}" condition="is" value="3"]

Cold fermentation time

You can ferment your pizza dough over 24 hours or 48 hours. If choosing 24 hours, your bulk fermentation (room temperature) will be done over 24 hours, and the final 24 hours will be done in the fridge (this means less yeast). If choosing 48 hours, your bulk fermentation will be done over 4 hours, and the final 44-48 hours will be done in the fridge (requires more yeast)
[/gravityforms]

Ingredients

Flour: {Hidden - Total Flour (gm):20} gm

Water: {Hidden - Total Water (gm/ml):21} gm

Yeast: {Hidden - Total Yeast (gm):22} gm

Salt: {Hidden - Total Salt (gm):23} gm

Sugar: {Hidden - Total Sugar (gm):25} gm

Oil: {Hidden - Total Oil (gm):24} gm

Ingredient tips!
[gravityforms action="conditional" merge_tag="{When do you want it?:229:value}" condition="isnot" value="1"]

Starter fermentation method

You can ferment your starter by leaving it at room temperature or placing it in the fridge for a cold fermentation. For the best results, we recommend opting for the cold fermentation method.
[/gravityforms]

Room Ferment

[gravityforms action="conditional" merge_tag="{When do you want it?:229:value}" condition="is" value="1"]

Final Fermentation (4 hours)

For a 'same day' pizza, you will want to finalise your dough fermentation at room temperature
Before covering with plastic wrap, you may want to prepare a separate bowl and lightly spread olive oil around the bowl. Transfer the dough mixture to this bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. This will make it easier to transfer the dough to your kitchen bench later for preparing the dough balls
[/gravityforms] [gravityforms action="conditional" merge_tag="{When do you want it?:229:value}" condition="is" value="2"]

Final Fermentation (16-24 hours)

For a 'next day' pizza, you will want to finalise your dough fermentation in your fridge overnight (about 16-24 hours)
Before covering with plastic wrap, you may want to prepare a separate bowl and lightly spread olive oil around the bowl. Transfer the dough mixture to this bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. This will make it easier to transfer the dough to your kitchen bench later for preparing the dough balls
[/gravityforms] [gravityforms action="conditional" merge_tag="{When do you want it?:229:value}" condition="is" value="3"]

Final Fermentation (16-24 hours)

For a '2 day' pizza, you will want to finalise your dough fermentation in your fridge over two nights (about 40-48 hours)
Before covering with plastic wrap, you may want to prepare a separate bowl and lightly spread olive oil around the bowl. Transfer the dough mixture to this bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. This will make it easier to transfer the dough to your kitchen bench later for preparing the dough balls
[/gravityforms]

Pizza Size
fields.jbTooltipContent: How big would you like your pizza?

fields.label: Number of pizzas
fields.jbTooltipContent: The amount of pizzas you would like.

fields.label: Do you want to make your pizza dough?

choices.text: No, I already have dough ready
Yes, I would like to make the dough

fields.label: When do you want it?
fields.jbTooltipContent: This determines the preperation time for your pizza. The longer the preparation time, the better the flavour and texture of the pizza. For best results, choose '2 days' here.

fields.label: Yeast type
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the yeast type that you will be using. The most common type of yeast is 'Active Dry Yeast'. The label on your yeast packet/container should state whether it is Active or Instant. Fresh yeast is not as common (as dry yeasts) in western countries, and is more likely to be found only in specialty stores.

fields.label: Starter
fields.jbTooltipContent: You can use a starter for your pizza dough for better and more traditional results. Different pizza types can use different starters. Only the starters appropriate for your pizza type are available here. If you would like to customise your own pizza type, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: Starter
fields.jbTooltipContent: You can use a starter for your pizza dough for better and more traditional results. Different pizza types can use different starters. Only the starters appropriate for your pizza type are available here. If you would like to customise your own pizza type, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: Starter Statement
fields.content:
This type of dough requires a Sourdough starter. Click on our Sourdough starter recipe link to learn how to create one!
Learn the recipe!

fields.label: HTML Block
fields.content:
Dough adjustments
We've chosen the best dough settings based on your pizza selection, however if you're an advanced pizza creator, feel free to change them.

fields.label: Hydration (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent:
This is the % of water that will be used compared to the total flour. For example, if the hydration is set to 60% and the total flour is 100gm, then the water will be 60gm. 

The most common hydration has been selected for your pizza type.

fields.label: Sourdough Starter (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of Sourdough starter you will make your total pizza dough with. For example, if you are making a 100g ms dough ball, and you use 20% of Sourdough starter, then your sourdough starter will be 20 gms.

fields.label: Biga flour (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of the total flour you want to use for your starter. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered!

fields.label: Poolish flour (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of the total flour you want to use for your starter. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered!

fields.label: Salt (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of salt you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Sugar (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of sugar you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Oil (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of oil you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Dough Balls
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is basically the number of pizzas you have chosen. Each dough ball will form 1 x pizza.

fields.label: Dough Ball Weight
fields.calculationFormula:
if({Pizza Size:220} == 10):
((((10/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 11 ):
((((11/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 12 ):
((((12/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 14 ):
((((14/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 16 ):
((((16/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 18 ):
((((18/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 20 ):
((((20/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 100001):
((({Pizza Length (cm):242}*{Pizza Width (cm):243})*{Dough Weight Per Square CM:255}))
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 100002):
((({Pizza Length (inches):248}*{Pizza Width (inches):247})*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254}))
else:
  0
endif;
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the recommended dough ball weight for your chosen pizza. If we prefer to customise your own dough ball weight, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: RT Leavening time (hours)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the recommended Room Temperature (RT) leavening/fermenting time for your starter or dough (in the beginning). If you prefer to customise your own temperature, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: Yeast %

fields.label: Show dough calculator results?
fields.description: You can view the breakdown of ingredients from our dough calculator based on your selections above. Otherwise go straight to the recipe (don't worry, the ingredients will be displayed on the next step as well).

fields.label: Hidden - Sourdough Flour gm
fields.calculationFormula: ({Dough ball weight (gms):4}*{Number of pizzas:246})/((({Hidden - Sourdough Total Percentages:245}/100)+({Sourdough Starter (%):114}/100))+1)

fields.label: Hidden - Sourdough Salt gm
fields.calculationFormula: (({Hidden - Sourdough Starter gm:124}/2)+{Hidden - Sourdough Flour gm:115})*({Salt (%):17}/100)

fields.label: Hidden - Sourdough RT Ferement Time
fields.calculationFormula:
if({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 15):
18
elseif({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 20):
12
elseif({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 25):
8
elseif({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 30):
4
else:
  0
endif;

confirmations.name: Default Confirmation
confirmations.message:
1. Preparing the Poolish Starter

1) Add the {Hidden - Poolish Water (gm/ml):27}gms of water to a bowl. Make sure it's luke warm 2) Now add the {Hidden - Poolish Yeast (gms):28}gms of yeast and the {Hidden - Poolish Sugar (gms):56}gms of sugar into the bowl and stir well. Let this sit for about 10 minutes before the next ste. 3) Now add the  {Hidden - Poolish Flour (gm):26}gms of flour and mix until all is combined. 4) Now let this sit for {Leavening time (hours):12} hours at {RT Temperature (celsius):7} celsius. 5) After {Leavening time (hours):12} hours, you're now ready to move to step 2 'Making the dough'

2. Making the dough

1) Once your poolish is ready, it's time to start adding the remaining ingredients to form your pizza dough. 2) Take a mixing bown, and add {Hidden - Dough Flour (gms):29} gms of flour to the bowl 3) Now add {Hidden - Dough Water (gm/mil):30} gms/mls of water to the bowl 4) Now add {Dough Salt (gms):70} gms of salt to add some flavour 5) Also add {Dough Oil (gms):71} gms of oil to the bowl 6) And now add your starter or poolish to the bowl and mix all together 7) Once all mixed together...............

Ingredient tips!

Biga Starter

Mix your starter

{Hidden - Biga Flour gm:129} gms of Type 00 Flour {Hidden - Biga Water gm:128} gms of Water {{Hidden - biga Yeast gm:127} gms of {Yeast type:6} Yeast.

Rest

After 16-24 hours, your Biga starter will be ready for making your final pizza dough

Dough Mix

Mix in Dough

It is now time to mix the dough ingredients into your starter
OPTIONAL: At this point, you can get extra air into your pizza dough by doing a 'slap and fold' of your pizza dough and letting rest for an additional 1-2 hours. See the video below for an example of how to slap and fold

Additional ingredients:

Flour or Semolina: 1 cup to flour surfaces / bowls and to flatten dough balls

Sourdough Starter Recipe

Dough Mix

fields.label: Pizza Size
fields.jbTooltipContent: How big would you like your pizza?

fields.label: Number of pizzas
fields.jbTooltipContent: The amount of pizzas you would like.

fields.label: Do you want to make your pizza dough?

choices.text: No, I already have dough ready
Yes, I would like to make the dough

fields.label: When do you want it?
fields.jbTooltipContent: This determines the preperation time for your pizza. The longer the preparation time, the better the flavour and texture of the pizza. For best results, choose '2 days' here.

fields.label: Yeast type
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the yeast type that you will be using. The most common type of yeast is 'Active Dry Yeast'. The label on your yeast packet/container should state whether it is Active or Instant. Fresh yeast is not as common (as dry yeasts) in western countries, and is more likely to be found only in specialty stores.

fields.label: Starter
fields.jbTooltipContent: A starter is a natural leavening agent used in pizza dough to enhance flavor and texture. Choose a starter that matches your pizza style from the options provided. If you're unsure, leave the default selection 'None'. For custom pizza types, use our advanced calculator (advanced calculator).

fields.label: Starter
fields.jbTooltipContent: A starter is a natural leavening agent used in pizza dough to enhance flavor and texture. Choose a starter that matches your pizza style from the options provided. If you're unsure, leave the default selection 'None'. For custom pizza types, use our advanced calculator (advanced calculator).

fields.label: Starter Statement
fields.content:
This type of dough requires a Sourdough starter. Click on our Sourdough starter recipe link to learn how to create one!
Learn the recipe!

fields.label: HTML Block
fields.content:
Dough adjustments
We've chosen the best dough settings based on your pizza selection, however if you're an advanced pizza creator, feel free to change them.

fields.label: Hydration (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent:
This is the % of water that will be used compared to the total flour. For example, if the hydration is set to 60% and the total flour is 100gm, then the water will be 60gm. 

The most common hydration has been selected for your pizza type.

fields.label: Sourdough Starter (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of Sourdough starter you will make your total pizza dough with. For example, if you are making a 100g ms dough ball, and you use 20% of Sourdough starter, then your sourdough starter will be 20 gms.

fields.label: Biga flour (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of the total flour you want to use for your starter. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered!

fields.label: Poolish flour (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of the total flour you want to use for your starter. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered!

fields.label: Salt (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of salt you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Sugar (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of sugar you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Oil (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of oil you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Dough Balls
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is basically the number of pizzas you have chosen. Each dough ball will form 1 x pizza.

fields.label: Dough Ball Weight
fields.calculationFormula:
if({Pizza Size:220} == 10):
((((10/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 11 ):
((((11/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 12 ):
((((12/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 14 ):
((((14/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 16 ):
((((16/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 18 ):
((((18/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 20 ):
((((20/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 100001):
((({Pizza Length (cm):242}*{Pizza Width (cm):243})*{Dough Weight Per Square CM:255}))
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 100002):
((({Pizza Length (inches):248}*{Pizza Width (inches):247})*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254}))
else:
  0
endif;
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the recommended dough ball weight for your chosen pizza. If we prefer to customise your own dough ball weight, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: RT Leavening time (hours)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the recommended Room Temperature (RT) leavening/fermenting time for your starter or dough (in the beginning). If you prefer to customise your own temperature, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: Yeast %
HTML Block
fields.content: How do you want to display the results?

fields.label: Show dough calculator results?
fields.description: You can view the breakdown of ingredients from our dough calculator based on your selections above. Otherwise go straight to the recipe (don't worry, the ingredients will be displayed on the next step as well).

fields.label: Hidden - Sourdough Flour gm
fields.calculationFormula: ({Dough ball weight (gms):4}*{Number of pizzas:246})/((({Hidden - Sourdough Total Percentages:245}/100)+({Sourdough Starter (%):114}/100))+1)

fields.label: Hidden - Sourdough Salt gm
fields.calculationFormula: (({Hidden - Sourdough Starter gm:124}/2)+{Hidden - Sourdough Flour gm:115})*({Salt (%):17}/100)

fields.label: Hidden - Sourdough RT Ferement Time
fields.calculationFormula:
if({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 15):
18
elseif({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 20):
12
elseif({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 25):
8
elseif({Sourdough Starter (%):114} <= 30):
4
else:
  0
endif;

confirmations.name: Default Confirmation
confirmations.message:
1. Preparing the Poolish Starter

1) Add the {Hidden - Poolish Water (gm/ml):27}gms of water to a bowl. Make sure it's luke warm 2) Now add the {Hidden - Poolish Yeast (gms):28}gms of yeast and the {Hidden - Poolish Sugar (gms):56}gms of sugar into the bowl and stir well. Let this sit for about 10 minutes before the next ste. 3) Now add the  {Hidden - Poolish Flour (gm):26}gms of flour and mix until all is combined. 4) Now let this sit for {Leavening time (hours):12} hours at {RT Temperature (celsius):7} celsius. 5) After {Leavening time (hours):12} hours, you're now ready to move to step 2 'Making the dough'

2. Making the dough

1) Once your poolish is ready, it's time to start adding the remaining ingredients to form your pizza dough. 2) Take a mixing bown, and add {Hidden - Dough Flour (gms):29} gms of flour to the bowl 3) Now add {Hidden - Dough Water (gm/mil):30} gms/mls of water to the bowl 4) Now add {Dough Salt (gms):70} gms of salt to add some flavour 5) Also add {Dough Oil (gms):71} gms of oil to the bowl 6) And now add your starter or poolish to the bowl and mix all together 7) Once all mixed together...............

[gravityforms action="conditional" merge_tag="{When do you want it?:229:value}" condition="is" value="3"]

Cold fermentation time

You can ferment your pizza dough over 24 hours or 48 hours. If choosing 24 hours, your bulk fermentation (room temperature) will be done over 24 hours, and the final 24 hours will be done in the fridge (this means less yeast). If choosing 48 hours, your bulk fermentation will be done over 4 hours, and the final 44-48 hours will be done in the fridge (requires more yeast)

fields.label: **** Pizza Square Inch Value ****
Pizza Size
fields.jbTooltipContent: How big would you like your pizza?

fields.label: Number of pizzas
fields.jbTooltipContent: The amount of pizzas you would like.

fields.label: Do you want to make your pizza dough?

choices.text: No, I already have dough ready
Yes, I would like to make the dough

fields.label: When do you want it?
fields.jbTooltipContent: This determines the preperation time for your pizza. The longer the preparation time, the better the flavour and texture of the pizza. For best results, choose '2 days' here.

fields.label: Yeast type
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the yeast type that you will be using. The most common type of yeast is 'Active Dry Yeast'. The label on your yeast packet/container should state whether it is Active or Instant. Fresh yeast is not as common (as dry yeasts) in western countries, and is more likely to be found only in specialty stores.

fields.label: Starter
fields.jbTooltipContent: You can use a starter for your pizza dough for better and more traditional results. Different pizza types can use different starters. Only the starters appropriate for your pizza type are available here. If you would like to customise your own pizza type, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: Starter
fields.jbTooltipContent: You can use a starter for your pizza dough for better and more traditional results. Different pizza types can use different starters. Only the starters appropriate for your pizza type are available here. If you would like to customise your own pizza type, please go to the advanced calculator.

fields.label: Starter Statement
fields.content:
This type of dough requires a Sourdough starter. Click on our Sourdough starter recipe link to learn how to create one!
Learn the recipe!

fields.label: HTML Block
fields.content:
Dough adjustments
We've chosen the best dough settings based on your pizza selection, however if you're an advanced pizza creator, feel free to change them.

fields.label: Hydration (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent:
This is the % of water that will be used compared to the total flour. For example, if the hydration is set to 60% and the total flour is 100gm, then the water will be 60gm. 

The most common hydration has been selected for your pizza type.

fields.label: Sourdough Starter (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of Sourdough starter you will make your total pizza dough with. For example, if you are making a 100g ms dough ball, and you use 20% of Sourdough starter, then your sourdough starter will be 20 gms.

fields.label: Biga flour (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of the total flour you want to use for your starter. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered!

fields.label: Poolish flour (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of the total flour you want to use for your starter. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered!

fields.label: Salt (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of salt you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Sugar (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of sugar you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Oil (%)
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the percentage (%) of oil you want to use for your dough. This shoudl be between 1-3%. If you're not sure, just leave this as the default...we got you covered! The percentage is measured again your total flour, for example, if your total flour is 100gms and you choose 1%, then it will equate to 1gm.

fields.label: Dough Balls
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is basically the number of pizzas you have chosen. Each dough ball will form 1 x pizza.

fields.label: Dough Ball Weight
fields.calculationFormula:
if({Pizza Size:220} == 10):
((((10/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 11 ):
((((11/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 12 ):
((((12/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 14 ):
((((14/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 16 ):
((((16/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 18 ):
((((18/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 20 ):
((((20/2)^2)*3.14159)*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254})
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 100001):
((({Pizza Length (cm):242}*{Pizza Width (cm):243})*{Dough Weight Per Square CM:255}))
elseif( {Pizza Size:220} == 100002):
((({Pizza Length (inches):248}*{Pizza Width (inches):247})*{Dough Weight Per Square Inch:254}))
else:
  0
endif;
fields.jbTooltipContent: This is the recommended dough ball weight for your chosen pizza. If we prefer to customise your own dough ball weight, please go to the advanced calculator.

confirmations.name: Default Confirmation
confirmations.message:
1. Preparing the Poolish Starter

1) Add the {Hidden - Poolish Water (gm/ml):27}gms of water to a bowl. Make sure it's luke warm 2) Now add the {Hidden - Poolish Yeast (gms):28}gms of yeast and the {Hidden - Poolish Sugar (gms):56}gms of sugar into the bowl and stir well. Let this sit for about 10 minutes before the next ste. 3) Now add the  {Hidden - Poolish Flour (gm):26}gms of flour and mix until all is combined. 4) Now let this sit for {Leavening time (hours):12} hours at {RT Temperature (celsius):7} celsius. 5) After {Leavening time (hours):12} hours, you're now ready to move to step 2 'Making the dough'

2. Making the dough

1) Once your poolish is ready, it's time to start adding the remaining ingredients to form your pizza dough. 2) Take a mixing bown, and add {Hidden - Dough Flour (gms):29} gms of flour to the bowl 3) Now add {Hidden - Dough Water (gm/mil):30} gms/mls of water to the bowl 4) Now add {Dough Salt (gms):70} gms of salt to add some flavour 5) Also add {Dough Oil (gms):71} gms of oil to the bowl 6) And now add your starter or poolish to the bowl and mix all together 7) Once all mixed together...............

confirmations.name: ONLY Toppings Recipe Description
confirmations.message:
Your pizza creation process involves 2 steps.

Navigate through your creation journey using the tabs below

Preheat your oven

Preheat your oven now so it's ready once you're toppings are done

Once your toppings are prepared, move to the next step, 'Cook'

NOTE: The recommended cheese for a Detroit style pizza is Wisconsin Brick cheese. Alternatively you can use another high fat cheese like Monterey Jack or a mild white cheddar.
